_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RMP PROGRAM

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 

COLUMBIA FRUIT PACKERS



Columbia Fruit Packers (hereafter referred to as Columbia Fruit) is a fruit packing and cold storage facility, located at 2575 Euclid Ave, Wenatchee, WA, in the county of Chelan.  Anhydrous ammonia is used on-site in the refrigeration system.  Ammonia is considered hazardous by EPA and is listed on the Extremely Hazardous Substance (EHS) list.  Chemical properties of ammonia make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling ammonia in order to:

   *  Prevent unnecessary human exposure

   *  Reduce the threat to our personnel

   *  Reduce the threat to the community and environment



Columbia Fruit's accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures, and management practices.  It is the policy of Columbia Fruit to adhere to all applicable federal and state safety and environmental regulations.



Columbia Fruit's emergency response plan recognizes the health risks of exposure to high levels of anhydrous ammonia. Columbia Fruit has not trained its refrigeration personnel in hazardous materials response.  In case of an incident involving the release of ammonia, employees are trained to move to the assembly area determined by the Evacuation Coordinator.  The Chelan County Fire District #1 will respond to the incident and take control upon arrival.  The Fire Department's Hazmat team will be responsible to enter the facility, if needed. Chelan County Fire District is located within one mile of the facility. 





There are 21,300 pounds of anhydrous ammonia in the refrigeration system.  The Euclid Plant has two separate systems (Plant 1 and Plant 2).  Plant 1 has approx 6,500 lbs of ammonia and Plant 2 has approx 14,810 lbs.  The ammonia is not shared between the two plants, and buildings are around 300 feet apart.  The closed refrigeration system moves the ammonia through a series of vessels, tanks and piping.  The many safeties within

the system, allow for easy isolation of any part of the system at any given time.  



Columbia Fruit uses other hazardous substances on-site, however they do not meet or exceed the threshold limits established in 40 CFR 68.130.  



Columbia Fruit has established policies, procedures and training to reduce the risk of an accidental hazardous substance release for the safety of its employees and surrounding areas.



Columbia Fruit's accidental release prevention program is based on the following key elements:

  * High level of training of personnel

  * Preventative maintenance program

  * Written safety procedures and safety equipment

  * Use of accurate and effective written operating procedures



Columbia Fruit also complies with: 

  * OSHA and Washington State process safety management rule

  * Applicable Washington State safety regulations (WACs 296-24 and 296-62)

  * IIAR (International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration) standards for good work practices

  * Applicable local fire code for handling of hazardous materials



The ammonia refrigeration system was installed to applicable codes and good practices at the time of installation.  Piping is elevated to prevent accidental damage to the system from moving vehicles.  Engine room doors are tight fitting and open outwards.  Other safety devices Columbia Fruit utilizes include:

  * Computerized controls, which can be operated remotely

  * Suction trap hi-level float

  * High discharge pressure shut down

  * Low suction pressure shut down

  * High discharge temperature shut down

  * Oil pressure failure shut down

  * High amperes shut down

  * Automatic timer to prevent short cycling

  * Oil filters plugged shut down

  * 250 psi relief valves on high pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations

  * 150 psi relief valves on low pressure side, to prevent overpressure situations

  * Emergency ventilation



Operating Procedures have been prepared by Columbia Fruit to be used by employees

performing operational functions.  The operating procedures are kept in the engine room.  These procedures include: 

  * Pre-start up procedures

  * Routine operations

  * Maintenance

  * Response to minor releases

  * Emergency shut down 

  * Emergency action plan



Columbia Fruit has not had any accidents involving ammonia in the last five years.



In addition to the operating procedures, Columbia Fruit has established Emergency Response Guidelines for releases involving ammonia.  These procedures are part of the ongoing training.  Annual Evacuation Drills are also part of this training.  Chelan County Fire Department has received a copy of Columbia Fruit's Emergency Response Plan, and have toured the facility. 



Refrigeration personnel have received appropriate technician level training from the Ammonia Safety Training Institute (ASTI).



Columbia Fruit will continue to ensure that its employees assigned to work on the process receive current training.
